I hope the Administration will take another look at my bill with @SenRobPortman, the National Park Service Legacy Act, because it really begins to solve this $11.6 billion problem.

The point here is we need a bipartisan solution that doesn‚Äôt just put a band-aid on the problem. If we want to preserve the beauty and history of our national parks for future generations, we need to work together to fully fund the National Park Service‚Äôs maintenance backlog.
That doesn't mean new taxes or new drilling, just spending our money more wisely and solving the problem.

I introduced a bill last year with @SenRobPortman that has a straightforward solution: use existing money already collected by the federal government from oil and natural gas revenues to fix our parks.
Here‚Äôs a better idea:

tl;dr ‚Äì Tying funding for national parks maintenance to unrealistic projections about the price of oil doesn‚Äôt solve much of anything in the long run. Frankly, it puts us right back where we started.

The Administration has started to come around to the idea of using existing revenue to fix this problem. Unfortunately, they‚Äôve landed on an idea, supported by some Democrats, that isn‚Äôt sustainable in the long term.
https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/policy/energy/democrats-fight-over-ryan-zinkes-plan-to-use-energy-revenue-to-fix-national-parks

First, the Trump Administration proposed hiking fees on our national parks, sticking families with the costs of Congress‚Äô mismanagement. No one liked that idea, prompting the #HikeTrailsNotFees backlash and forcing the administration to reconsider its position.
Most people agree that something must be done to address our national parks maintenance backlog. The problem, as usual, is how you pay for it.

Virginia ranks 5th in terms of states with the greatest need for maintenance. Over $800 million in deferred maintenance has left Shenandoah, Jamestown, Fredericksburg, the Blue Ridge Parkway, and other national parks in need of significant repairs.

Unfortunately, years of underfunding has produced a massive $11.6 billion (with a B) maintenance backlog at our national parks. Many are in a critical state of disrepair. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DbkkPzNXkAA6j5G.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DbkkRSTWsAIPhQX.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DbkkSSrX4AE9NSU.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/DbkkTQzXkAEtTif.jpg
